Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of Harpocrates wearing festival wreath headdress with two lotus buds and the double crown of Egypt and his left index finger to his mouth. Mould-made and hollow. White (gypsum?) coating and red paint on hair. Brown Nile silt fabric. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz, organics and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Gutch dated this piece to between 150BC and 250AD (Hogarth 1899, no.186). This is from the same mould as another piece dated by Bailey to the 2nd or 1st century BC, excavated during the same season, and now in the British Museum (GR 1886,0401.1406 , Hogarth 1899, no.185; Walters 1903, C574; Bailey 2008, no. 3079; Gutch 1898–9, 92n. 2 and 93n. 8). This is similar to one now at Dresden dated to the early second century BC (Fischer 1994, 286, no. 653). Fischer, J. 1994. Griechisch-römische Terrakotten aus Ägypten. Die Sammlungen Sieglin und Schreiber. Dresden, Leipzig, Stuttgart, Tübingen. Tübingen, Wasmuth.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.062) (Phase 1)
Gutch 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis, D. The Terracottas (p. 92, no. 186)
